snippet: A Louisiana scandal points to pervasive exploitation of legal guest workers. Congress needs to make sure that profits are not built upon the erosion of workplace conditions and laborers’ rights.
abstract: Editorial contends that Wal-Mart's suspension of C J's Seafood, one of its suppliers, for violating its workplace standards is a reminder of the pervasive exploitation of legal guest workers that occurs in the United States; calls on Congress and the Department of Labor to issue new rules protecting workers' rights.
lead_paragraph: A Louisiana scandal points to pervasive exploitation of legal guest workers. Congress needs to make sure that profits are not built upon the erosion of workplace conditions and laborers’ rights.
